Award.AwardTitle: Early Career Participant Support for a Chapman Conference in Selfoss, Iceland on Arctic Magmatism and Tectonics
Award.AbstractNarration:
This travel award will provide support for six early career scientists from the U.S. to attend an international Chapman conference on Arctic magmatism. The purpose of the conference is to synthesize understanding of geology and geophysics of the Arctic Ocean and the surrounding continents and to identify areas ripe for future research. To inform the broader scientific community, the organizers will publish a white paper summarizing these points and also will hold a post-conference session at the American Geophysical Union's Fall 2020 meeting.

This project ensures early career scientists from the U.S. will be able to participate in an upcoming AGU Chapman Conference in Selfoss, Iceland, Large-scale Volcanism in the Arctic: The Role of the Mantle and Tectonics. It will focus on five themes: 1) Pre-breakup rifting; 2) seafloor spreading; 3) mantle-derived heterogeneity (including plumes and large-igneous provinces); 4) subduction related volcanism; and 5) High Arctic Large Igneous Province and environmental effects extending from the Paleozoic to the present day.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Our understanding of the tectonic evolution of the Arctic has advanced dramatically in recent years. Expanding datasets and a deeper knowledge of geophysical and geodynamic processes have the community grappling to understand the connection between magmatic evolution and tectonics of the Arctic continents and ocean. This Chapman Conference brought together investigators, working in the Arctic and elsewhere, to catalyze this process. 


The Chapman conference on Large-Scale Volcanism in the Arctic was held in Selfoss, Iceland, 13-18 October 2019. The meeting brought together 80 scientists from diverse specialties to discuss the role of volcanism in forming the Arctic Region. The strength of the meeting was bringing together Arctic specialist with specialists from other regions as well as senior and early career scientists. During 94 independent presentations, the participants educated each other about the history of the Arctic and about new techniques to apply to this relatively unknown region.


The present-day Arctic Ocean can be divided into two basins, the Cenozoic Eurasia Basin and the Mesozoic Amerasia Basin. These basins are distinct in terms of opening kinematics, the timing of initiation and the status of understanding.  The two basins were subject to voluminous magmatism including rifting, seafloor spreading and subduction related processes, raising questions about the role of the underlying mantle. This meeting provided the opportunity to see distinctly how all major Arctic tectonic events since the Paleozoic have been influenced by magmatism.


Addressing hypotheses about magmatism in the Arctic offers a unique opportunity to link the surface and deeper evolution of the region. The AGU supported this Chapman Conference to provide a forum to assemble this scientific community and examine hypotheses such as: Can persistent Arctic mantle heterogeneity explain the complexity of the Arctic’s tectonic and volcanic evolution? How can volcanic events be used to test alternative tectonic models for the region? Can a single, unifying definition of the High Arctic Large Igneous Province (HALIP) be adequately constrained? 


To achieve this, the conference focused on Arctic magmatism across five themes; Theme I: pre-breakup rifting; Theme II: seafloor spreading; Theme III: mantle-derived heterogeneity (including plumes and large-igneous provinces); Theme IV subduction related volcanism and Theme V: HALIP and environmental effects.  Within this context, particular effort was dedicated to refining the concept of the High Arctic Large Igneous Province, but sessions included topics that extend from the Paleozoic to present-day.


The meeting was held in Iceland as it offered an ideal analogue for Arctic magmatism; it features long-lived volcanism, a mantle plume, and plate tectonics. Located on the mid-Atlantic Ridge it also offered a convenient and cost-efficient meeting place for North American and European-based participants. Over five days of lectures and discussions, the conference brought together members of the Arctic community (including but not limited to petrologists, geochronologists, paleomagnetists, marine geophysicists, and structural geologists) as well as specialists from other communities with an understanding of magmatism across all scales.


Intellectual Merit
Complicated by sea ice-coverage and remoteness, new data has slowly accumulated from the Arctic Ocean Basins, it’s isolated archipelagos, and adjacent continents. These data, collected by independent investigators, must be reconciled to develop new constraints that can be used to test and refine geophysical and geodynamic models for the region. The international Arctic and magmatic communities benefited from a concerted, collective effort to better understand the principle processes controlling the formation of the two Arctic Ocean basins.


Broader Impacts
The US is an Arctic nation. It is natural for US scientists, some of whom are were involved in meeting planning, to participate. We welcomed 80 participants to Selfoss for these discussions. While the US was well represented, the European Arctic Nations (e.g. Norway and Russia in particular) were also well represented. This proposal funded 7 US-based early career scientists to participate in the meeting. Early career scientists participated in all aspects of the conference. We believe this opportunity to work together towards common scientific goals will catalyze progress and facilitate greater international collaboration.
